com.complexible.stardog.sesame

Class StardogRepositoryConnection

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.openrdf.repository.base.RepositoryConnectionBase
      • com.complexible.stardog.sesame.StardogRepositoryConnection
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    org.openrdf.repository.RepositoryConnection

    public final class StardogRepositoryConnection
extends org.openrdf.repository.base.RepositoryConnectionBase

    Stardog-based implementation of a Sesame RepositoryConnection. Stardog RepositoryConnection's have autoCommit turned OFF by default; this differs from other RepositoryConnection implementations where this option is ON by default. autoCommit turned ON will yield sub-optimal performance with Stardog because of the overhead of pushing many single statement transactions. So do not enable autoCommit unless absolutely required by your application.

    These connections keep a local cache of changes which are not pushed until they exceed a threshold, or an action, such as a query or a commit, requires them to be pushed to the server. This minimizes the overhead of calling add or remove in a tight loop with small payloads and then committing the entire thing, those updates would then be pushed in as few chunks as possible.

    It should also be noted that all queries created via this connection will implement the accessors for a query's maxQueryTime, dataset, and includeInferred as no ops. The methods will work in that they will not throw an UnsupportedOperationException, however, they are not currently supported by the backing Stardog implementation. includeInferred is somewhat of an exception as this can be considered to be true (and immutable) if the underlying connection supports reasoning, thus, in these cases Operation.getIncludeInferred() will always return true.

    Each of the specific prepare*Query methods, such as RepositoryConnectionBase.prepareGraphQuery(org.openrdf.query.QueryLanguage, String) will parse the query during invocation, but it will not be type checked until execution time. For example, you can provide a valid ASK query to prepareGraphQuery and it will not fail that you're using a boolean query as a graph query until its executed. This is similar to how HTTPRepository handles this situation.

    Since:
    0.1
    Version:
    2.2.1
    Author:
    Michael Grove
